Comment: Hello everybody :) This time I would like to present a game played against my buddy vkoval, in which I will demonstrate how important it is to fully develop all of your pieces in the game. So, let's move on - hope you enjoy it!
I usually start with an "open" opening and this is a typical move my opponent is used to make against 1. e4.
Moving on to French Defence, which is one of my most hated openings. I always seem to fall into trouble in this one.
Typical play by black. I usually play 3. e5 to avoid the exchange variation, in which I do not see any good attacking possibilities.
As said.
Again, a typical move.
Secures d4.
This move prevents white from activating it's bishop, since b2 is under attack.
As far, everything according to the book. I was expecting 5. ... Nc6, however, my opponent played differently.
After this move I can develop my light-squared bishop. If vkoval had played 5. ... Nc6, this would not be possible since the d4 pawn would be left unguarded.
This move also prevents 6. ... Nf5.
What? Wasn't d8-d6 a better way to develop? I think so, and now black has lost a tempo and blocked the c6 square with his other knight.
Clears the path for the Queen to guard the d4 pawn. Also places the bishop strategically on a fully opened b1-h7 diagonal.

Hmm... This move brings the second knight into play, but blocks the path for the bishop as well. Morover, is there any place this knight could move on with the next move? Only to its origin square I guess.
Castling brings the rook into play. My opponent is at least two moves from making a castle.
He prepares for it nevertheless.
This move unblocks white's dark squared bishop. It can now take an active spot on b2 or the c1-h6 diagonal.
Purpose of this move by black is to bring the d7 knight into the game.
White takes, otherwise the center is lost.
Knight retakes and takes a good defensive spot.
